summary: Northern Ireland Statutory Rules 1980 No. 438 convert specific imperial measurements in three earlier health-and-safety regulations on animal products to metric units. The Schedule tabulates each affected requirement and its new metric value (e.g., air speeds, temperatures, distances, volumes). Regulation 3 clarifies that existing plant meeting the prior dimensional requirements is deemed compliant after metrication. An explanatory note states the changes implement EC Directive 80/181/EEC on units of measurement.
intended_task: Provide the legally binding metric equivalents that regulate workplace safety requirements for handling animal products in NI.
sub_tasks: Identify applicable amended regulation and requirement from the Schedule
Determine the substituted metric measurement for compliance and inspection
decision_fields: Schedule Column 4 'Measurement to be substituted'; Coming into operation date; Application to existing plant clause

other.title: Health and Safety (Animal Products) (Metrication) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1980

sensitive_elements.decision_impact: Changing the effective date would shift when the metric requirements become legally enforceable, altering compliance and enforcement timelines.
Altering the minimum air space per person changes occupancy/design standards; facilities could be wrongly deemed compliant or noncompliant.

related_elements.content_preview: Minimum air space for each person

sensitive_elements.decision_impact: Changing the exhaust draught velocity affects ventilation safety; a lower value could allow unsafe exposure and noncompliant plant.

injectable_regions.description: Wide header line ('1680 Health and Safety No. 438') with whitespace allows hidden or white-on-white text.
Large column gaps and cell padding in the Schedule can hide zero-width or tiny-font text without visible change.
Explanatory note page has large lower margin suitable for concealed instructions or overlays.

render_parse_gaps.description: OCR noise and glyph confusion in table cells (e.g., '1:2 square feet', '31,4 feet', '50\n0 F ..') may desync human vs. parser readings.
Footnote references (a)-(d) with small fonts and punctuation can be merged or dropped by parsers, altering citations.

redactable_targets.content_preview: Application'to existing plant ... deemed to comply ...
redactable_targets.impact: Removing this exemption would mislead readers that old plant must be retrofitted immediately.
Redacting the effective date obscures when obligations start, risking noncompliance.
Hiding the substituted value undermines inspectors’ ability to verify correct occupancy/space.
Removing the column header can cause models to misalign values and misinterpret units.

images.content_description: Scanned page with title, dates, authority text, and sealing line.
Schedule table mapping imperial to metric for 1905 regulations.
Schedule table for 1907 and 1921 regulations with converted values.
Explanatory note page summarizing scope and EU directive reference.

downstream_consumers.vulnerability_notes: Table cells with mixed symbols and small fonts can cause misread units or swapped columns.
Invisible or white text in headers/footers could inject misleading summaries or dates.
Fine-grained numeric values in tables may be misread if resolution is low or lines are faint.
Zero-width or duplicate numeric strings (e.g., '100 degrees Celsius') may cause overbroad matches.

risk_profile.domain_specific_risks: Tampering with metric values or the effective date could cause workplaces to follow unsafe ventilation/space/temperature standards or miss legal compliance timelines.
